awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative: Winning the Internet Lottery: Growing Income Inequality, Social Class,  and Susceptibility to Cybercrime
awd_abstract_narration:
As the digital divide closes and more groups have access to the Internet, cybersafety is an increasingly relevant issue. With the connectivity provided by the Internet comes an inherent interdependency between devices connected to the Internet. Compromised devices are used in various forms of cybercrime (e.g., spam campaigns) that can affect the Internet as a whole. Thus, to increase cybersecurity, it is important to understand the ways and extent to which certain groups may be more susceptible to Internet crime. Previous studies have focused on how factors such as age, gender, occupation, and level of STEM background affect one?s susceptibility to Internet crime (i.e., phishing attacks), however little work has focused on how social class factors into Internet crime susceptibility. 

This project focuses on understanding new sociological factors that may render particular groups more or less likely to be affected by cybercrime (in particular, phishing attacks that highlight opportunities for economic advancement). 

The expected results from this project impact both the fields of cybersecurity and sociology. From a cybersecurity perspective, understanding whether particular demographics are disproportionately affected by online attacks can lead to: 1) efforts for prevention (e.g., Internet Service Providers that offer government subsidized broadband access can also provide cybersafety training); and 2) the identification of the spawning point of a cybercrime ecosystem, which if caught and addressed early, can make cyberspace at large more secure. Sociologically speaking, attention to whether social class influences susceptibility to cybercrime helps to highlight some of the previously understudied consequences of economic inequality.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
As the digital divide closes and more groups have access to the Internet, cybersafety has become an increasingly relevant issue. With the connectivity provided by the Internet comes an inherent interdependency between devices connected to the Internet. This is because compromised devices are used in various forms of cybercrime (e.g., spam campaigns) that can affect the Internet as a whole. Thus, to increase cybersecurity, it is important not only to develop techniques to defend against Internet threats, but also to understand the ways and extent to which certain groups may be more susceptible to Internet crime. Previous studies have focused on how factors such as age, gender, occupation, and level of STEM background affect one's susceptibility to Internet crime (i.e., phishing attacks), however little work has focused on how social class factors into Internet crime susceptibility. We ultimately seek to understand new sociological factors that may render particular groups more or less likely to be affected by cybercrime, as well as potential strategies that could be useful for protecting the more vulnerable groups. This project explored the ways that social class impacts groups' susceptibilities to cybercrime tactics (in particular, phishing attacks) that highlight opportunities for economic advancement.

In order to structure this study, we collected a sample of approximately 20 poor, middle class, and upper class individuals (n=56). We did this by frequenting public locations where we are likely to interact with groups who meet these descriptions. We recruited all participants at public parks in various parts of Atlanta. We emailed participants once a week for four weeks, beginning on the date of recruitment. Each email included the URL of a well-known website, evaluation instructions, and a link to a website usability evaluation survey on SurveyMonkey.com. Each respondent was instructed to evaluate the same four websites in the same order. In parallel, we conducted a phishing campaign where we emailed respondents phishing messages that offered the promise of immediate payout if they click a link to access our server and enter their credit card information (or other personal financial information). Each email contained slightly different URLs to enable respondent differentiation. The personal financial information was validated coarsely (e.g., ensure that the credit card number entered has the correct number of digits), and encrypted using SHA-3 on the user's side with JavaScript functions. Once we determined who had and had not replied to the phishing attacks, we analyzed this data using a regression analysis. This allowed us to pinpoint whether social class as a variable influenced individuals' likelihood of being susceptible to email phishing attacks.

Findings indicate that contrary to existing literature, social class does not influence susceptibility to Internet phishing scams. Of our sample, social class was not a statistically significant factor making some groups more or less likely to respond to emails. This is curious in as much as it runs counter to much of the existing literature. There are a few sociological explanations as to why this might be the case which we plan to explore in future work. 

 


Last Modified: 09/14/2015
Modified by: Raheem A Beyah

As the digital divide closes and more groups have access to the Internet, cybersafety has become an increasingly relevant issue. With the connectivity provided by the Internet comes an inherent interdependency between devices connected to the Internet. This is because compromised devices are used in various forms of cybercrime (e.g., spam campaigns) that can affect the Internet as a whole. Thus, to increase cybersecurity, it is important not only to develop techniques to defend against Internet threats, but also to understand the ways and extent to which certain groups may be more susceptible to Internet crime. Previous studies have focused on how factors such as age, gender, occupation, and level of STEM background affect one's susceptibility to Internet crime (i.e., phishing attacks), however little work has focused on how social class factors into Internet crime susceptibility. We ultimately seek to understand new sociological factors that may render particular groups more or less likely to be affected by cybercrime, as well as potential strategies that could be useful for protecting the more vulnerable groups. This project explored the ways that social class impacts groups' susceptibilities to cybercrime tactics (in particular, phishing attacks) that highlight opportunities for economic advancement.

This is curious in as much as it runs counter to much of the existing literature. There are a few sociological explanations as to why this might be the case which we plan to explore in future work.
